bucket_descriptions.self_control_fatigued: Aware of the issue and repeatedly attempts fixes, but slips under stress and exhaustion.
bucket_descriptions.social_motivated: Behavior changes most when trusted peers can see progress and provide light pressure.
bucket_descriptions.privacy_guarded: Interested in the outcome but evaluates data-sharing risk before trying anything.
bucket_descriptions.deletion_rebounder: Uses app deletion as a temporary tactic and consistently returns to old patterns.
bucket_descriptions.skeptical_optimizer: Needs mechanism transparency and evidence before adopting new tools.

personas.name: Noah Wright
personas.relevant_history: Asked roommates to hold them accountable, but nobody kept it consistent past 7-day period one.
personas.in_their_voice: If it helps me recover after slips, I'd keep using it.

personas.name: Emma Young
personas.relevant_history: Keeps setting nightly app limits during exam 7-day periods, then turns them off after one stressful day.
personas.in_their_voice: I don't need another strict rule, I specifically need something that catches me before a two-hour spiral.

personas.name: Liam Green
personas.relevant_history: Uses bedtime alarms, but late-night doomscrolling still cuts into sleep before classes.
personas.in_their_voice: I really want consistency, not another all-or-nothing streak.

personas.name: Olivia Chen
personas.relevant_history: Moved social social apps off the home screen, yet still opens them by search reflex when tired.
personas.in_their_voice: Small wins help me more than hard restrictions.

personas.name: Ava Wright
personas.relevant_history: Did two digital detox 7-day periodends; Monday routines erased most gains.
personas.in_their_voice: I hate feeling like I start from zero every week.

personas.name: Elijah Young
personas.relevant_history: Tries phone-in-drawer study blocks but grabs the phone during short breaks and loses the next hour.
personas.in_their_voice: If missing once feels like failure, I stop trying at all.

personas.name: Mia Green
personas.relevant_history: Keeps 'fresh start' goals every month and feels discouraged when the pattern repeats.
personas.in_their_voice: I specifically need guardrails that still work on my worst days.

personas.name: Lucas Chen
personas.relevant_history: Disabled notifications repeatedly; boredom, not pings, still triggered long scroll sessions.
personas.in_their_voice: My problem isn't knowing what to do, it's doing it when I'm tired.

personas.name: Amelia Wright
personas.relevant_history: Used grayscale mode and Focus modes for two semesters; both worked briefly before old habits returned.
personas.in_their_voice: I can do this for a few days, then one bad night knocks everything over.

personas.name: Ethan Young
personas.relevant_history: Switched to browser-only social access, then reinstalled social apps before midterms.
personas.in_their_voice: If it lowers the shame after a miss, I'm in.

personas.name: Sophia Green
personas.relevant_history: Uses Pomodoro timers, but social social apps consistently swallow the 5-minute break windows.
personas.in_their_voice: When I'm mentally drained, my thumb opens apps before I even think.

personas.name: James Chen
personas.relevant_history: Started a paper habit tracker for scrolling but stopped logging after missing three days.
personas.in_their_voice: I really want a reset button, not a punishment cycle.

personas.name: Isabella Wright
personas.relevant_history: Tries habit trackers repeatedly but sticks longer when a friend cohort is involved.
personas.in_their_voice: Group accountability beats any timer I've tried.

personas.name: Benjamin Young
personas.relevant_history: Shares workout recaps daily and expects similar consistency if screen-time wins are visible.
personas.in_their_voice: Shared momentum is what keeps me from quitting week two.

personas.name: Harper Green
personas.relevant_history: Prefers small private groups over broad social feeds for behavior-change accountability.
personas.in_their_voice: Make it feel like teamwork and I'll use it.

personas.name: Noah Chen
personas.relevant_history: Responds strongly to group challenges; tends to follow through when progress is visible to peers.
personas.in_their_voice: Friendly competition works on me way better than solo reminders.

personas.name: Emma Wright
personas.relevant_history: Finds solo habit social apps boring; engagement rises when friends can react or comment.
personas.in_their_voice: If friends can react to progress, I'll check in daily.

personas.name: Liam Young
personas.relevant_history: Finished a 30-day reading challenge because leaderboard nudges made progress feel social.
personas.in_their_voice: I don't need lectures, just a nudge from people I trust.

personas.name: Olivia Green
personas.relevant_history: Competes with close friends on step counts and wants similar low-friction accountability for attention.
personas.in_their_voice: A private squad view would keep me honest.

personas.name: Ava Chen
personas.relevant_history: Likes public goals but quits when social apps feel punitive instead of collaborative.
personas.in_their_voice: I really want light pressure, not public embarrassment.

personas.name: Elijah Wright
personas.relevant_history: Actually improved gym attendance from friend streaks and believes the same mechanic could work for screen time.
personas.in_their_voice: If my close friends can see progress, I actually follow through.

personas.name: Mia Young
personas.relevant_history: Uses shared calendars with friends and follows commitments better when others can see progress.
personas.in_their_voice: Seeing my friends improve would push me to improve too.

personas.name: Lucas Green
personas.relevant_history: Stays motivated when there is playful pressure, not shaming or hard penalties.
personas.in_their_voice: If it's playful, I'll come back; if it's harsh, I'll churn.

personas.name: Amelia Chen
personas.relevant_history: Joined a study Discord with 7-day periodly check-ins and reduced procrastination when others posted updates.
personas.in_their_voice: I stick with habits longer when there's a group doing it together.

personas.name: Ethan Wright
personas.relevant_history: Had a past experience with unwanted data sharing, now defaults to minimal disclosure tools.
personas.in_their_voice: Show me the privacy controls first, then I'll consider onboarding.

personas.name: Sophia Young
personas.relevant_history: Concerned friends might misread usage stats without context on school/work demands.
personas.in_their_voice: Private-by-default is the only reason I'd test it.

personas.name: James Green
personas.relevant_history: Open to peer accountability, but only with revocable, friend-level visibility permissions.
personas.in_their_voice: Trust is the feature here, not just the dashboard.

personas.name: Isabella Chen
personas.relevant_history: Reviews data controls policies for retention windows and third-party sharing language.
personas.in_their_voice: I really want controls that make sense without digging through settings.

personas.name: Benjamin Wright
personas.relevant_history: Keeps separate public/private accounts to limit exposure and context collapse.
personas.in_their_voice: Don't make me trade personal data for basic functionality.

personas.name: Harper Young
personas.relevant_history: Wants accountability benefits but only with clear controls for what data is visible and to whom.
personas.in_their_voice: If sharing is all-or-nothing, it's a no for me.

personas.name: Noah Green
personas.relevant_history: Prefers aggregated summaries over raw app-by-app logs shared with others.
personas.in_their_voice: Transparency on data retention matters as much as features.

personas.name: Emma Chen
personas.relevant_history: Will try new social apps only if export/delete controls are easy to find and trusted.
personas.in_their_voice: I specifically need to revoke access instantly if I feel uncomfortable.

personas.name: Liam Wright
personas.relevant_history: Has turned off ad personalization everywhere; highly sensitive to behavioral telemetry collection.
personas.in_their_voice: Give me category-level sharing and I can work with that.

personas.name: Olivia Young
personas.relevant_history: Uses aliases on social platforms and rarely links accounts across services.
personas.in_their_voice: I really want accountability, not exposure.

personas.name: Ava Green
personas.relevant_history: Rejected prior focus social apps because permission requests felt unrelated to core functionality.
personas.in_their_voice: I'll share trends, not every app detail.

personas.name: Elijah Chen
personas.relevant_history: Avoids social apps that ask for broad device permissions and reads data controls settings before signup.
personas.in_their_voice: I can try this, but only if I decide exactly who sees what.

personas.name: Mia Wright
personas.relevant_history: Uninstalls when sleep is affected, reinstalls when feeling socially disconnected.
personas.in_their_voice: I can quit for a week, then I overcorrect the next week.

personas.name: Lucas Young
personas.relevant_history: Has periodic success with deletion but no durable replacement habit for downtime moments.
personas.in_their_voice: If it reduces binges after reinstall, I'd pay attention.

personas.name: Amelia Green
personas.relevant_history: Removes social apps to focus on projects, then comes back for campus event coordination.
personas.in_their_voice: Social apps are how plans happen, so deletion isn't realistic.

personas.name: Ethan Chen
personas.relevant_history: Deletes TikTok during finals, reinstalls after exams, and repeats the cycle each month.
personas.in_their_voice: Deleting works for me until real life needs those apps again.

personas.name: Sophia Wright
personas.relevant_history: Switches to mobile web after deleting social apps, then eventually redownloads for convenience.
personas.in_their_voice: I don't want to disappear from my friends just to focus.

personas.name: James Young
personas.relevant_history: Finds deletion effective short-term but too isolating for friendships and group updates.
personas.in_their_voice: Help me stay connected without losing whole evenings.

personas.name: Isabella Green
personas.relevant_history: Tries short detoxes before deadlines; rebound usage often exceeds baseline afterward.
personas.in_their_voice: My issue is rebound, not awareness.

personas.name: Benjamin Chen
personas.relevant_history: Uses app blockers in bursts, then disables them when social planning happens in DMs.
personas.in_their_voice: Hard bans backfire; I specifically need a middle path.

personas.name: Harper Wright
personas.relevant_history: Keeps promising 'this is the last reinstall' but relapses during stressful 7-day periods.
personas.in_their_voice: I specifically need sustainable limits, not dramatic resets.

personas.name: Noah Young
personas.relevant_history: Used parental-control style locks on self; workarounds made the strategy collapse.
personas.in_their_voice: I really want fewer spirals, not total abstinence.

personas.name: Emma Green
personas.relevant_history: Moved social social apps to an old phone once, but carrying two devices proved unsustainable.
personas.in_their_voice: If this helps me cut time without going offline, that's useful.

personas.name: Liam Chen
personas.relevant_history: Removed Instagram three times last semester; each reinstall started with 'just for messages.'
personas.in_their_voice: I keep uninstalling and reinstalling, so I specifically need something between those extremes.

personas.name: Olivia Wright
personas.relevant_history: Questions whether social pressure changes behavior long-term or just creates novelty spikes.
personas.in_their_voice: I'm open, but I optimize by evidence.

personas.name: Ava Young
personas.relevant_history: Adopted productivity tools only after measuring 7-day period-over-7-day period impact on deep-work hours.
personas.in_their_voice: I specifically need to see how the signal maps to behavior change.

personas.name: Elijah Green
personas.relevant_history: Compares intervention tools by mechanism and retention data before committing to any routine change.
personas.in_their_voice: Show me measurable lift, not motivational copy.

personas.name: Mia Chen
personas.relevant_history: Tests social apps in two-7-day period pilots and drops anything without measurable outcomes.
personas.in_their_voice: I don't mind nudges if the math is transparent.

personas.name: Lucas Wright
personas.relevant_history: Concerned that gamification can shift focus from reduced scrolling to score-chasing.
personas.in_their_voice: Explain what 'improvement' means in concrete terms.

personas.name: Amelia Young
personas.relevant_history: Accepts nudges if they are configurable and tied to explicit goals.
personas.in_their_voice: If this only works as a gimmick, it won't last.

personas.name: Ethan Green
personas.relevant_history: Needs clear definitions of success metrics before paying for premium features.
personas.in_their_voice: Give me baselines and deltas so I can trust outcomes.

personas.name: Sophia Chen
personas.relevant_history: Values transparent methodology and wants to know how progress signals are computed.
personas.in_their_voice: I adopt tools that survive novelty decay.

personas.name: James Wright
personas.relevant_history: Looks for causal evidence, not testimonials, when evaluating attention-management products.
personas.in_their_voice: If setup takes ten minutes and value is vague, I'm out.

personas.name: Isabella Young
personas.relevant_history: Runs personal time audits in spreadsheets and distrusts vague behavior-change claims.
personas.in_their_voice: If this is better than blockers, prove the mechanism clearly.

personas.name: Benjamin Green
personas.relevant_history: Will adopt quickly if setup is low-friction and effect size is clearly demonstrated.
personas.in_their_voice: Make the experiment easy to run and evaluate.

personas.name: Harper Chen
personas.relevant_history: Has tried browser extensions with dashboards but abandoned those lacking actionable feedback.
personas.in_their_voice: Configurable goals plus clear reporting is what I specifically need.
